title: (x) Victorian Serifs - Elongated Roman, various alternatives {Mike Y, self (Michael A)}
content:
Greetings,

Anybody recognize the fonts used for "Archibald" and "Family Library"?:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202133017im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ARCHIBALD_4238.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202133017im_/http:/typophile.com/files/dreadful_5949.jpg)

Many thanks!
author: malbright

comments.content:
The FAMILY LIBRARY lettering is fairly close to Christian Schwartz's "Giorgio", designed for the NY Times. The sample below is from my Serif Guide. It has a lot of alternates, and possibly other widths as well.

[edit: I should credit the graphic as coming from the Schwartzco site]

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202133017im_/http:/typophile.com/files/giorgio_full_5453.gif)

Okay, so the "Family Library" font is actually Elongated Roman.

Mike, that was a really creative suggestion. What an eye! I never would've put that together.

Now we're just shooting for "Archibald."

Thanks, folks.

I think searching for Antique could help, but I stumbled across something similar while looking for another font. Check out [Teaberry](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202133017/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/4753-Teaberry) by William McChesney. In a pinch it might do, or could be modified to be close, I think.

- Mike Yanega

[[http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/figgins-tuscan/|Figgins Tuscan]] is another close style.

- Mike Yanega
Lovely suggestions, Mike. Very much appreciated!
